Introduction

Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone mineral density (BMD) and is associated with increased bone fragility and susceptibility to fractures.  It is often asymptomatic until a fracture (typically involving the hip, vertebrae, or wrist) occurs, but it is frequently detected by screening.  Osteoporosis is most common in postmenopausal women, but it also occurs in premenopausal women and in men.  Treatment is indicated for most patients with osteoporosis and can include both pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic measures.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of osteoporosis is based primarily on BMD assessment using dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA).  DXA measures 2-dimensional density (in g/cm2); the result is reported as a T-score, which is the standard deviations above/below the mean for a healthy young adult at peak bone density.  Diagnostic criteria are as follows:



  • Osteoporosis:  T-score â‰¤âˆ’2.5.
  • Osteopenia:  T-score between âˆ’1.0 and âˆ’2.5.


DXA reports also usually include a Z-score, which compares the measured density with age- and sex-matched norms.  A disproportionately low Z-score often suggests a secondary cause of osteoporosis, and it can help identify abnormal bone loss in men and premenopausal women who have a T-score in the normal range.



In patients with a low-trauma fracture (eg, hip or vertebral fracture), osteoporosis can be diagnosed without a BMD test.  However, DXA is still useful for following the response to treatment and course over time.

Treatment overview



Treatment of osteoporosis includes both pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic measures.  Pharmacologic therapy is indicated for most patients with osteoporosis (ie, T-score â‰¤âˆ’2.5 or confirmed fragility fracture) and for those with osteopenia who have increased fracture risk (eg, calculated 10-year risk for hip fracture â‰¥3% or combined major fracture risk â‰¥20%).  Fracture risk can be assessed using standardized clinical tools, such as the FRAX risk calculator (

); this tool estimates the 10-year risk for fracture in individuals age 40-90, taking into account clinical risk factors and, optionally, BMD at the femoral neck.

Nonpharmacologic interventions



All patients with osteoporosis should engage in regular weight-bearing (eg, walking) and muscle-strengthening exercise to maintain bone density and reduce susceptibility to falls.  Additional exercises for improving balance and flexibility may be useful for mitigating fall risk.  Diet should be oriented to maintain adequate calcium (eg, 1,200 mg/day) and vitamin D (eg, 800 IU/day) intake.  Calcium and vitamin D supplements are not always needed but are recommended for patients who are unable to achieve adequate intake through diet alone.

Pharmacologic treatment



Bisphosphonates (eg, alendronate) are widely used and are the preferred first-line medication for most patients.  Other options that may be appropriate in certain patients include Receptor Activator of Nuclear factor kappa-Î’ (RANK) ligand inhibitors (eg, denosumab), selective estrogen receptor modulators (eg, raloxifene), hormone replacement therapy, and anabolic agents (eg, teriparatide).

Bisphosphonates



  • Mechanism of action:  Bisphosphonates have a chemical structure similar to that of pyrophosphate and attach to hydroxyapatite binding sites on bone surfaces, preferentially in areas of increased bone turnover.  They inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption by the following mechanisms:

    • Reduced adherence of osteoclasts to the bone surface.
    • Decreased osteoclast acid production.
    • Increased osteoclast apoptosis.
    • Decreased development and recruitment of osteoclast precursor cells.
  • Indications:  First-line therapy for most patients, particularly men and postmenopausal women:
    • Alendronate (oral, weekly) and risedronate (oral, weekly or monthly) are commonly used.
    • Zoledronic acid (intravenous, yearly) is an option for patients unable to tolerate oral bisphosphonates and patients for whom reduced medication adherence is a concern.
  • Special considerations:  Oral agents have low bioavailability, especially if taken with food.  They must be taken whole on an empty stomach, 30-60 minutes before food or other medications.  They should be used cautiously in individuals with gastrointestinal intolerance or significant renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30-35 mL/min).  Potential complications of long-term use include osteonecrosis of the jaw (mandible or maxilla) and atypical bone fractures (eg, stress fractures of the subtrochanteric zone and femoral shaft); the risk for atypical fractures may be mitigated by limiting use to â‰¤5 years.  Because bisphosphonates limit the mobilization of calcium from bones, patients should maintain an adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D to avoid hypocalcemia.  Intravenous bisphosphonates are commonly associated with a brief flu-like syndrome (eg, fever, fatigue, myalgia).

Denosumab



  • Mechanism of action:  A monoclonal antibody that binds to RANK ligand, inhibiting the formation and activity of osteoclasts.
  • Indications:  Suitable for men and postmenopausal women with a high fracture risk or for those who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates.  Denosumab is also effective in patients with chronic kidney disease because it is not renally excreted.
  • Special considerations:  Denosumab is administered subcutaneously every 6 months.  Long-term use is associated with an increased risk for vertebral fractures on discontinuation, so transitioning to another therapy after discontinuation is advised.

Selective estrogen receptor modulators



  • Mechanism of action:  Selective estrogen receptor modulators (eg, tamoxifen, raloxifene) are nonsteroidal compounds that bind estrogen receptors and exhibit antagonist or agonist properties in a tissue-specific manner as follows:

    • Bone:  Raloxifene and tamoxifen have estrogen agonist activity on bone, which decreases bone resorption.
    • Breast tissue:  Raloxifene and tamoxifen have estrogen antagonist activity on breast tissue and decrease the risk for breast cancer.
    • Uterus:  Raloxifene acts as an estrogen antagonist in the uterus (no effect on endometrial cancer risk), whereas tamoxifen acts as an agonist and increases the risk for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.
  • Indications:  Tamoxifen is somewhat more effective than raloxifene for preventing invasive breast cancer and is frequently used in the treatment of estrogen-receptorâ€“positive breast cancer.  However, tamoxifen's agonist activity on the uterus significantly increases the risk for endometrial cancer; therefore, raloxifene is more appropriate for routine use to prevent osteoporosis.  Raloxifene reduces the risk for vertebral fracture but not for nonvertebral (eg, hip) fracture.
  • Special considerations:  Increased risk for venous thromboembolism and hot flashes.

Hormone replacement therapy



  • Mechanism of action:  Estrogen or estrogen-progestin therapy reduces bone resorption by osteoclasts.
  • Indications:  Hormone replacement therapy is effective for preventing bone loss in postmenopausal women, but because of the increased risk for cardiovascular events, breast cancer, and thromboembolism, it is not first-line treatment for most patients.  It may be considered in younger postmenopausal women with severe menopausal symptoms who are at risk for osteoporosis.
  • Special considerations:  Should be prescribed at the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration possible.

Anabolic agents



  • Teriparatide (parathyroid hormone 1-34):

    • Mechanism of action:  A recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity.
    • Indications:  Recommended for patients with severe osteoporosis (T-score <âˆ’3.0) or for those with multiple fractures.  It is also used in patients who cannot tolerate first-line antiresorptive therapy or for whom osteoporosis progresses despite treatment.
    • Special considerations:  Daily subcutaneous injections for up to 2 years.  After discontinuation, patients should be transitioned to antiresorptive therapy (eg, bisphosphonates) to maintain gained bone density.
  • Abaloparatide:  Similar to teriparatide, it stimulates bone formation.  It has similar indications and is given as daily subcutaneous injections.

Romosozumab



  • Mechanism of action:  A monoclonal antibody that inhibits sclerostin (a glycoprotein produced by osteocytes that suppresses osteoblast bone formation), leading to both increased bone formation and decreased bone resorption.
  • Indications:  Postmenopausal women with severe osteoporosis, particularly when other treatments have failed or are not tolerated; administered as monthly subcutaneous injections for 12 months.
  • Special considerations:  Contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or stroke.

Nasal calcitonin



Nasal calcitonin is not routinely used for chronic management of osteoporosis due to modest efficacy and possible increased risk for certain malignancies (eg, hepatocellular carcinoma).  However, it can be used to provide short-term pain relief following a vertebral compression fracture.

Thiazide diuretics



Thiazide diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone) reduce renal calcium excretion and likely provide a small reduction in osteoporosis risk.  They are often considered for patients with hypertension who have an increased risk for osteoporosis (eg, postmenopausal women).

Monitoring response to therapy



Periodic reassessment with DXA is indicated to monitor response to antiresorptive therapy.  Typical intervals include 1-2 years following initiation of therapy and again a few years later.  Shorter intervals may be inadequate to detect changes outside the margin of error of the test but may be appropriate for patients with rapid bone loss (eg, chronic glucocorticoid therapy).  A significant fall in T-score or a new fragility fracture should prompt consideration of a change in therapy.

Summary



Osteoporosis is a common disease that is typically asymptomatic until it presents with fractures.  Identifying at-risk individuals and using nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic interventions are the keys to managing the disease.  Early diagnosis, appropriate use of diagnostic tools such as dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry, and treatment with bisphosphonates or other agents can slow disease progression and improve outcomes.
